* 18Ã All-Star (1963, 1965, 1966, 1967, 1968, 1969, 1970, 1971, 1972, 1973,

* Boston Red Sox #8 retired |hofdate=1989 |hofvote=94.63% first ballot }} 'Carl
  Michael Yastrzemski' (; nicknamed '"Yaz"'; born August 22,
  1939) is a former American Major League Baseball left fielder and first
  baseman. [http://www.baseball-
  reference.com/players/y/yastrca01.shtml Carl Yastrzemski at Baseball
  Reference] He was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1989. [http://baseballhall.org/hof/yastrzemski-
  carl Carl Yastrzemski at the Baseball Hall of Fame] Yastrzemski played
  his entire 23-year baseball career with the Boston Red Sox (1961â1983). He was
  primarily a left fielder, with part of his later career played at first base
  and as a designated hitter. Yastrzemski is an 18-time All-Star, the possessor of seven Gold
  Gloves, a member of the 3000 hit club, and the first American League player in
  that club to also accumulate over 400 home runs. [http://b-
  ooks.google.com/books?id=ghEWLhenYM8C&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26&dq=carl+yastrzemski+ca-
  reer+accomplishments&source=bl&ots=5LdmxlL7Nd&sig=03DTHHmxqAJGKrK681HdgwLuTVU-
  &hl=en&ei=29GVS-
  iDPM2WlAfW5uT6AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CA8Q6AEwAzgU#v=o-
  nepage&q=carl%20yastrzemski%20career%20accomplishments&f=false Rawlings
  Presents Big Stix: The Greatest Hitters in the History of the Major Leagues,
  Rob Rains, Sports Publishing LLC, 2004, ISBN 1-58261-757-0, ISBN 978-1-58261-757-
  2] He is second on the all-time list for games played, and third for
  total at-bats. He is the Red Sox' all-time leader in career RBIs, runs, hits,
  singles, doubles, total bases, and games played, and is second on the team's
  list for home runs behind another Red Sox great, Ted Williams, his predecessor
  in left field. In , Yastrzemski achieved a peak in his
  career, leading the Red Sox to the American League pennant for the first time
  in over two decades, in that season being voted the American League MVP, and
  was the last winner of the Triple Crown for batters in the Major Leagues until
  Miguel Cabrera achieved the feat in 2012. [http://www.baseball-reference.com/leagues/AL/1967-batting-
  leaders.shtml 1967 American League Batting Leaders at Baseball
  Reference] [http://www.baseball-
  reference.com/awards/awards_1967.shtml#ALmvp 1967 American League Most
  Valuable Player Award voting resultsa at Baseball Reference]
